head.title: Police Investigating Vandalism at Door Of Bronx Synagogue

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Police Investigating Vandalism at Door Of Bronx Synagogue

abstract.p: Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel in Riverdale section of Bronx is vandalized, hours before start of Yom Kippur; police are investigating attack, in which bottle of purplish liquid was thrown against entrance door (S)

block.p: A Bronx synagogue was vandalized yesterday, hours before the start of Yom Kippur.

The police were investigating the attack, in which a bottle of purplish liquid was thrown against an entrance door at the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, at West 250th Street and the Henry Hudson Parkway, at 9 a.m. The attack caused initial concern that someone had thrown a firebomb, but the police had ruled out that possibility by the afternoon.

The police were investigating the attack, in which a bottle of purplish liquid was thrown against an entrance door at the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, at West 250th Street and the Henry Hudson Parkway, at 9 a.m. The attack caused initial concern that someone had thrown a firebomb, but the police had ruled out that possibility by the afternoon.

As the police were investigating, Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx left the Hispanic Day Parade on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan to meet with synagogue leaders. He issued a statement condemning the incident, calling it a bias attack.
''The perpetrators will be hunted down and prosecuted,'' Mr. Ferrer said.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani also traveled to the Bronx after hearing of the incident. ''The mayor wanted to reassure everyone,'' said his spokeswoman, Sunny Mindel.
The attack came after a week in which some Jewish and Palestinian residents in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, said they were worried that the violence in the Middle East might be replicated in New York.

In Brooklyn last week, vandals struck a synagogue and painted anti-Semitic graffiti on a Jewish cemetery, and two Jewish men reported being attacked. In the first attack, a Hasidic man was slashed on Oct. 1 as he strolled along Eighth Avenue in Sunset Park, by an assailant who identified himself as Palestinian. In the second attack, a Jewish man told the police that he was kicked as he left a B train at the Fort Hamilton Parkway station, by a man who some witnesses said was with a group carrying a Palestinian flag.
